Eu explicarei em detalhes porque eu acho que esse jogo é muito melhor que sua sequência na minha futura review de Half-Life 2, mas analisando apenas o tom do jogo é possível perceber qual é o melhor:

Half-Life 2: Gordon "Jesus Cristo" Freeman é um herói que vai liberar os cidadãos de uma grande tirania.

Half-Life 1: Gordon Freeman é um físico muito chad que conseguiu sobreviver ao incidente de Black Mesa, adquirindo 386 sintomas de PTSD junto como os outros protagonistas das expansões, especialmente o Shepard.
Simply put, one of the most revolutionary games of all time. It didn't age perfectly in some ways, but it certainly was a perfect game in its early days.

If you can ignore the demented community surrounding this game, you're bound to fall in love with the entire series.


Just don't play Black Mesa. It's riddled with bugs the devs refuse to fix.

Half-life is a classic, and while it can be kind of janky by today's standards it's still an awesome game. The moment to moment play experience is very enjoyable as the weapons are fun and the enemies have lots of variety. The unbroken narrative and spectacle of Half-Life is still amazing to this day, and the visuals, sound design, and music add up to make a very memorable game. It can be confusing and too hard in some spots, but overall Half-Life is a very good game that everyone with a PC should experience.

The original Half-Life is a clunky, yet really charming late 90's first person shooter. I really enjoyed my time with this game despite how old it is and how used I am to modern fps mechanics. I still say this game is worth playing just to see how far fps games have come in the past decades.

[h1]TL; DR[/h1]
This game has undeniably aged. It's still a good game, arguably a great one, by modern standards, but the fact that its influence is so vast and powerful means that most of modern games employ its techniques, and as such, most of the "surprises" in this game are staples of modern FPS design. Its shadow is greater than itself, and in parts, the game has turned into a history lesson more than anything.

[h1]They're waiting for you, Gordon... in the test chamber.[/h1]
"What makes a good game?"
This is the question that crawls in my mind when I sit to review this game. Should one take its historic context? Its lineage, its influence? Or should one just take its state as-is and review it like any other game of the present era?

Here's what I think: if you have any interest in the history of first-person-shooters, this game is a MUST. Its influence is one of the most reverberating of its time and its shadow looms over many classics of today, such as Counter-Strike, TF2 and Borderlands. Not only that, but for its era, it had a lot of impressive features such as dynamic storytelling and robust enemy AI.

On the other hand... well, look, it's not a bad game, not even by modern standards. Its pacing works well, its enemy roster is creative enough and the gunplay feels pretty good. But other than that, when played today, Half-Life is not that good. I mean, it's good, but it's not unmissable.

Due to the amount of influence it has, if you have played any modern shooter campaign, you kind of already played Half-Life in a way. Not only that, but its story, while somewhat mysterious and arguably intriguing, is still way too basic and non-specific to genuinely wow anyone. It has some great setpieces, and it also has some pretty boring sections. It's, you know, a normal game.

So... yeah, I do feel it gets a bit overrated at times, but not in the sense that it "was never that great to begin with", just that it has... aged. It was great, and now, well... it's just good.

半条命很经典，但是以现在来看，这款游戏我已经不推荐新玩家来玩了。

枪的弹道很奇怪，敌人的攻击判定也很离谱，虽然我困难模式通关了，但是整体的游戏体验是并不好的，游戏有些刻意的“为了难而难”了，而且脚底有点抹油的感觉，很滑，操作手感略微奇怪。如果这款游戏放在n年前，那么它很成功，但是这款游戏如果放在现在，真的没什么怀旧来玩的必要，选择云通关可能是体验半条命一代更佳的方式。

半条命1是游戏界经典之作，但是它也只能是经典之作了。

I'm actually in between on whether to recommend this game, but I'm leaning toward No. The first 80% or so of the game is awesome and really fun. Pretty funny at times, even. The last 20% is a nightmare. Like many older games, it struggles with difficulty progression and ramps up the difficulty to the point where it almost feels like a different game. Everywhere becomes a labyrinth filled with countless enemies you're never equipped with quite enough ammo for, all the while it starts making you utilize the antiquated movement system to make complex maneuvers while getting attacked on all sides. Quick saving is your friend - always. Honestly I mostly recommend it, but maybe just watch a playthrough for the remaining 20% because while I did complete it - I kinda wish I had saved my sanity and just watched someone else do it. 6/10
